title: Sub Question 1
stimulusHtml:
3 points maximum

1 point: the speaker: Mercury

2 points: total the occasion (2 pts. for full answer, 1 pt. for a partial answer.)

Elements:

sent by Jupiter/gods

lingering in Carthage

Carthage/Rome

needs to fulfill destiny

first of two speeches by Mercury to Aeneas

title: Sub Question 2
stimulusHtml:
2 points maximum

1 point: Latin/English x 2. Student names two out of three:

a) gloria (tantarum rerum): glory (of such great events) — the fact that his mission itself is glorious

b) (tua) laude: (for your own) praise/honor/glory — personal honor/ glory

c) moliris laborem: undertaking a task
descriptions:

title: Sub Question 3
stimulusHtml:
3 points maximum

The appeal to Aeneas’ pietas in lines 4-6 (N.B. Question does not require student to quote the Latin)

1 point: some understanding of pietas (directly stated or implied) as duty or obligation; more than English piety

1 point: father/son connection

1 point: development/explanation that applies pietas to this particular situation — references to Ascanius’ coming of age, the value of Ascanius as Aeneas’ heir, and the idea that Ascanius’ destiny is to rule Italy/Roman lands
